The details that form the images and sounds of Grace's mind are fast, disembodies, almost surreal as -- Judith's horse bulldozes into Pilgrim, taking his legs out from under him, sending both horses careening down the icy slope. Grace hangs onto Pilgrim's neck. Judith, her leg helplessly tangled in the stirrup, is dragged, her head bouncing on the frozen ground. They slide all the way back down to the COUNTRY ROAD. Pilgrim is the first to find his legs and stand. Grace manages to sit up in the saddle. She sees Judith's horse stumbling back onto its feet, one of his legs broken at the ankles, walking in confused circles, dragging Judith -- her face bleeding, her leg hanging from the stirrup.

The Truck, an 18 wheeler carrying logging equipment, comes around the turn... Grace grabs the bridle, trying to get Judith's horse out of the road... The driver, seeing them, lays on the air horn. The Horses bolt at the sound, the bridle slipping out of Grace's hand...

direction.raw_text: !!! ... The horses turn apart. The Driver starts furiously downshifting, trying to brake... He seems to get it under control when suddenly THE TRUCK SKIDS on some ice. It begins to slide, out of control, the truck bed and the cab jack- knifing. The truck literally plows over the helpless Judith and her horse -- the horse going down on the pavement, Judith disappearing under him. The truck's cab, like a mythic monster, heads right for Grace and Pilgrim... Grace looks right into the Driver's helpless, frightened eyes... Suddenly, Pilgrim rears up at the truck, sending Grace flying, bouncing her off the pavement and under the wheel of the truck. Pilgrim instinctively jumps onto the hood of the truck, his hooves caught between the rear-view mirrors like some grotesque ornament. His head and chest slams into the window, shattering through the glass. And then it is still. The truck has stopped halfway in the road. Judith's horse lies in the road, motionless. Pilgrim, on the truck's hood, his legs splayed, stuck, his head and chest, bleeding. He shrieks, struggling to get to his feet. He manages to free his legs and, stepping off the cab onto the road, walks off, wounded, in pain, into the sanctuary of the woods... The Driver stumbles out of the cab, his head bleeding, in shock. He sits on the ground. All we hear is the sound of the river and the wind in the trees. Grace, halfway under the truck, frozen, stares up at the beautiful morning sky.

direction.raw_text: Pilgrim is hiding in the shadows under an old railroad bridge, standing up to his knees in the river. His chest is cut open, bleeding. His face cut, contorted and swollen. LIZ HAMMOND, the local veterinarian, hides a hypodermic needle in her jacket, quietly walking into the water. A Policeman is going into the water downstream from Pilgrim, whose chest is heaving, blood drips into the water. He watches Liz. She is almost to him when suddenly he bolts, running upstream. The Policeman behind him shouts and waves his arm. Frightened, Pilgrim wheels back toward Liz, who manages to stick the hypo in his neck. He rears, knocking her down, then runs out of the river, the hypo still in his neck. He runs for the sanctuary of the woods.

direction.raw_text: Annie opens the door and enters, flicking on the light. Camera is on her back, as she places a small suitcase on the bed and opens it. She begins her task with cool efficiency. Opening drawers and closets, assessing what should be taken, what isn't necessary. Suddenly, she stops. She feels disoriented for a moment. She can't remember the last time she was inside this room. She takes a moment to pause and actually look around. In the light, we now see more of Grace's inner sanctum. Horse riding prize ribbons in various colors adorn the walls. Books. A girl's bureau cluttered with teenage possession ranging from childhood toys to items that suggest a reaching towards adulthood. Annie examines some items, affectionately. A GOOD LUCK CHARM from India sits among her things. Annie takes it to pack in the suitcase. She notices a framed 8X10 of Grace sitting proudly atop Pilgrim with Judith at her heel. She then notices the edge of another picture behind this one, in the frame. She pulls the Pilgrim photo out to reveal: An old 8X10 of Annie hugging Grace as a toddler. direction.raw_text: Annie enters. No one else is there. She places the suitcase on a chair and opens it. She takes out the INDIAN LUCKY CHARM and some horse books, and places them on her bedside table. She takes care to prop up the Lucky Charm. She wets a cloth with some water from a pitcher and gently wipes Grace's sweaty brow... INSERT VISUAL FLASHBACK HERE, instead of in Country House. Annie then continues unpacking the suitcase. She opens Grace's closet and sees a hospital bag filled with Grace's clothes at the time of the accident. Annie examines them and discovers they are hers. Annie shoves the clothes into a bag and starts unpacking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Clock is ticking on the wall. The cafeteria is empty except for one tired Intern, drinking coffee on a break. Robert and Annie are having a cup of coffee. In the silence, they search for things to say. Until:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw Judith's parents while you were at the apartment... (Annie listens) I wanted to say something... (beat) But I... I was so relieved that Grace was still... that it wasn't our daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're very lucky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The funeral's on Friday. He rises and crosses to the self-help coffee dispenser as he continues...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, uh, I meant to tell you... Alex brought that fabric over...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's on the table by the phone. I didn't know what to tell him... (returns to table, sits) ... Whether or not we were... (beat) ... if we still we're thinking of redoing the couch. Annie just nods. She senses Robert is looking for some kind of reassurance, but she can't give it to him. He continues;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... And uh... Mario called about moving the wisteria?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Right. I'll call him. Pause. Annie looks at her husband as he stares off to the side, deep in his thoughts. She can sense he's sinking as he fidgets with the napkins. She remembers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A younger Annie stands in a bathrobe, noticeably pregnant, cooking at a stove -- reading instructions from a propped up cookbook. FRANK SINATRA IS BLASTING as she sings along, in full voice, without inhibitions;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... SHE NEVER BOTHERS WITH PEOPLE SHE HATES... THAT'S WHY THE LADY IS A TRAMP!..." A younger Robert, wearing a suit, arrives home from work. Seeing her, he smiles affectionately. He puts down his briefcase and bursts into his own playful Sinatra impersonation:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "She loves the free..." Startled, Annie turns around and smiles:
direction.name: direction

result.heading: SHE NEVER BOTHERS WITH PEOPLE SHE HATES
THAT'S WHY THE LADY IS A TRAMP
ANNIE "SHE'S LOVES THE THEATRE BUT NEVER COMES LATE

direction.raw_text: ... FRESH, WIND IN HER HAIR... LIFE WITHOUT CARE... SHE'S BROKE... BUT IT'S 'OK'...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sing it to me, Frankie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's my pregnant chick! She moves to him and they embrace... He wraps his arms around her. They kiss. Annie laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can hardly get your arms around me. How depressing. You're so early.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had to excuse myself from a meeting. It's ridiculous. I kept thinking about the baby... you... and, I swear, I was going to start bawling right into my briefs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aw... that's so sweet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you? Do you really? They turn to each other and kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie and Robert sit silently at the table in an empty hospital cafeteria, a lifetime later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room's lights are dimmed. Dawn is being to break through. Grace, slowly, opens her eyes coming out of sedation. She takes a moment to figure out where she is... to remember. She uses her hands to hoist herself up, but she's unsteady and knocks into her bedside table -- knocking the Good Luck Charm from India off the table. It rolls under the bed, with a water tumbler. Grace never sees the Charm. Grace looks where her leg once was. She feels the blanket, the empty space where her leg once was... just like her mother did (did her father couldn't). Instead of self-pity, she's oddly fascinated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daylight pours in. Robert and Annie enter. Robert, loaded with gifts, immediately crosses to Grace, on the side of her good leg. Annie takes her position beside the lost leg. Robert kisses his daughter;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, sweetheart... Annie's hand finds Grace's hand, and holds one of her fingers tightly. Grace responds by wrapping her hand around her mother's. They exchange a look of respect and gratitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you heard from Judith's parents?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's Pilgrim doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liz is taking care of him. (to change the subject) The doctor said the sooner you start therapy the better the chances are you can -- GRACE I can't even get out of bed yet! You're already putting me in therapy!! Annie, slightly hurt, drops it as Robert takes over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doctor said whenever you're ready. Take your time. You tell us... But he thinks it'll only be a few months, then -- As Robert continues talking, Annie drifts to the Nurse. Needing to manage something, she asks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you get her fresh towels?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A limousine drives up as the Doorman gets the car door. The weather is slightly warmer. People's clothing looks as if spring is coming nearer. Annie exits first, carrying a jacket for Grace. She is followed by Robert, who immediately turns to help Grace. We hear her O.S.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad! I can do it, OK?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Annie shoots him a disapproving look. We see Grace's good leg exit first... then two crutches, followed by... a PROSTHETIC LEG. Grace scoots into view, and takes a breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You all go ahead. I'll be up by Christmas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three sit at a dinner table, eating dinner. Grace picks at her food. Robert can't help staring at her. Annie eats, watching them both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want something else, honey? We order something else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm just not that hungry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you go lie down?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to lie down. I've been lying down enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to watch some television?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe... look -- just... Robert and Annie wait. She doesn't continue. She rises, reaching for her crutches. Robert moves to help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got it! I got it! She exits into her room. Annie looks at him disapprovingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie and Robert stand before their separate sinks, talking to each other through their separate mirrors, as they wash up for bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got to stop doing that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doing what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helping all the time! Running to her every time she trips or falls... Anticipating her all the time. Robert shuts off his sink and dries his face, without a word. He exits into the bedroom, and gets into bed. For a beat, he stares up at the ceiling -- then says quite plainly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, Annie, this didn't just happen to you. Annie is applying moisturizer when she hears this. As it sinks in, she doesn't like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace stands by her door and can hear her parents muffled, tense voices. Annie is angry at his complacency. Robert just wants what's best for Grace. She closes the door. Silence. She puts her crutches against the wall and tries to walk towards her bureau without them. It is a struggle, but she does... almost falling, but grabbing the bureau just in time. The 8X10 of her and Pilgrim, falls face down. She props it up and looks at it -- focusing on her horse, then on Judith. Suddenly, she lashes out, knocking the photograph onto the floor...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey, you all right? Did something fall?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie pulls up in a Range Rover and stops. Grace moves for the door. Annie asks respectfully;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want any help? Grace doesn't even bother to answer. She manages to get onto the pavements, then turns for her bag... Annie notices other kids looking at Grace from behind, as they enter the school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad'll pick you up today, all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Grace looks up to her mother. What is unspoken between them is the understanding that today will be difficult and there's nothing either one can do about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be fine. Grace nods and turns to the school. Annie watches her go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace makes her way through the hall. It is the first time she has had to maneuver through a crowd. Some of the younger children are especially unconscious. Grace sweats her way through, trying to maintain her balance and her sanity. As Grace slowly moves along, whatever small faith she had that she could get through this day, begins to diminish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie moves about the office, hands in pocket, in front of her wall of windows. LUCY and her staff sitting around the office. Annie is speaking to a YOUNG WOMAN staff member;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't care what he told you! The man's a liar! The man's an actor, for Christ's sake. They're all liars! They'll say anything to get a cover... The Young Woman looks insulted. AN ASSISTANT comes in to give Annie a note;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie is crossing an empty school yard. Grace is sitting on the ground, her back against a wall, her "legs" in front of her. She has been crying. She looks up to her mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too hard. Annie kneels before her sympathetically brushing her hair away:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, honey... What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't matter. I... I don't want to come back, that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Well, what are you going to do? You have to go to school, honey. I mean, what -- GRACE (snaps) I'm not coming back! That's it! I want to go home!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace, listen to me. Your body is just healing. You have to give the rest of you time as well...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that your version of a pep talk?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are not staying home all day feeling sorry for yourself. You're going to get up and you're going to figure this out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's still early. What's your next class? With secret delight, Grace viciously utters the word:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gym!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie is at her desk studying Grace's book on Horse Whisperers. Robert is on his bed with briefs laid out before him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door is closed. A SONG blares on her stereo. Grace is in her bed watching a video of her and Pilgrim... riding at a horse show. There's a shot of Annie standing proudly, watching her ride. Another shot of her and Judith, both of them on their horses, waving to camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad? Both Robert and Annie look up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, sweetheart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to see Pilgrim. Robert and Annie exchange an anxious look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's raining. The MacLean car is parked by the barn. They are walking towards the stables under their umbrellas as Liz runs to greet them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello... (to Grace) It's so good to see you. How ya doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's doing just grea. Aren't you kiddo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, come on. He's out back now... (leads them) Mind how you go. It's pretty muddy back there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is he in the back? Why isn't he in the barn with the other horses? Liz stops, causing everyone to stop. She turns to face Grace, realizing she doesn't know. She looks at Robert and Annie, accusingly. She tries to explain:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Grace, you see... Pilgrim just... isn't the same horse he used to be. (to the parents) As a matter of fact, maybe now's not the best time to -- GRACE I really want to see him. Liz looks at Annie. Annie nods. Liz leads them on. They reach a row of empty old stalls. They cross to one of the stalls -- its doors are closed. Liz draws back the bolt on top half of the door. There is an immediate explosion of sound inside the stall, the sound of fear, startling them. Then it's still. Liz slowly opens the door. Grace, with the aide of her cane, walks to the stall. She hesitates, then looks in. It takes a moment for her eyes to grow accustomed to the dark. She sees Pilgrim with his head down in the shadows...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, beautiful boy... He lifts his head at the sound of her voice. Grace, and the audience, see him for the first time -- His mad eyes, his terrible disfigurement... Grace cries out, stepping backwards, nearly stumbling in the mud... What is left of her horse are gone. Annie realizes what's happened and, together with Robert, rush to her... They too see the monster Pilgrim has become and are horrified. Grace angrily pushes away from them and "runs" off. Robert goes after her. Annie is standing in the rain with Liz -- her eyes unable to move away from the sight of Pilgrim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should have told her, Annie. I tried to explain to you how bad it was... I guess you had to see it. But, there's nothing to be done. This animal's beyond help. Annie, can I have your permission now to put him down? Annie stands in the rain, hands in pocket, fixed on Pilgrim and more determined than ever;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alone in her study, Annie sits before her computer searching the Internet for information on HORSES -- Veterinarian Journals, Therapies, Accidents, Eistories... We sense she's been at it a while... She locates an ITEM TITLE -- HORSE WHISPERERS. Interested, she brings it up on the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie sits in the huge reading room, books spread out before her, under a green reading lamp. Her voice tells us what she's reading:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "It was in America that horses first roamed..." In the books, we see pictures, lithographs, paintings and drawings...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: million years before the birth of man, they grazed the vast empty plains of grass and crossed to other continents over bridges of rocks... They first knew man as the hunted knows the hunter, for long before man saw horses as a means to killing other beasts, man killed them for meat..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .O. CONTINUES OVER;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...The alliance with man would forever be fragile -- for the fear he'd struck into their hearts was too deep to be dislodged... Since that Neolithic moment when a horse was first haltered, there were those among men who understood this..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace sits alone in her darkened room, staring out the window but not looking at anything. There's a discomforting distance in her expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... They could see into the creature's soul and soothe the wounds they found there..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hot, dusty fairgrounds horse arena. The worn wooden bleachers, crowded. Lines of cars and pick-up trucks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...For secrets uttered softly into troubled ears, these men were known as The Whisperers..." One particular pick-up truck has its back door opened. A MAN'S LEG is sticking out, putting on a pair of boots. A moment later the Man gets out of the car. Holding a cowboy hat, he has a certain quality, a self-respect, that men who know themselves seem to have. TOM BOOKER. A weathered redheaded woman named RONA -- late forties, strong, wiry horsewoman's build -- is walking towards him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, darlin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Rona. Sorry I'm late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't know what to do if you were on time. They walk together towards the fairgrounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're looking fit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fit? You want to check my teeth. (Tom laughs) Good crowd today. I think you'll have some fun. You going to stay for dinner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it's not too much trouble, I thought I might.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kind of trouble I'm in the mood for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh-oh... Maybe I better get back in the truck. Rona lets out a hearty laugh as they enter the horse arena.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inside the corral, a small black thoroughbred is being worked by Tom. As he rides and narrates into a radio microphone to the crowd, we sense this is a man of good humor and great skill --  guileless, sensible, of the earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... It's always kind of interesting to hear the horse's side of the story... The crowd laughs warmly. He directs his comments to a WOMAN wearing an expensive Ralph Lauren western outfit, standing outside the corral...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now if he was cranky or lazy, like you say he is, we'd be seeing his tail twitching there and his ears back, maybe. But this isn't a cranky horse, it's a scared horse. You see how braced he is up around the neck back there. He just doesn't know which way to turn... The Woman nods. Tom turns the horse on a dime so that he always stays facing the circling thoroughbred...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see how he keeps pointing his hindquarters in at me? Well, I'd guess the reason he seems reluctant to move out is because when he does, he gets in trouble for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not good at transitions, you know? When I want him to move from a trot to a lope, say...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm sure that's what you think but that's not what I'm seeing. You may think you're asking for a lope, but your body may be saying something else altogether. You might be putting too many conditions on him. For instance, you might be saying "GO, but, hey, don't go too fast." He can tell that from the way you feel. Your body can't lie. You ever give him a kick to make him move out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't go unless I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then he goes and you feel like he's going too fast, so you yank him back? (she nods) And next thing you know, he's bucking. (she nods again) Well, if someone told you to go, stop, go, stop -- you'd buck too. The people laugh. The Woman smiles self-consciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a dance, see... Somebody has to lead and somebody has to follow. Tom gracefully moves his horse around the ring, "dancing". He then takes up a long coiled rope and throws it so that the coils slap against the black horse's flank, making it burst into a lope. And again... Making the animal go from a trot to a lope, letting it slow, then up to a lope again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want him to get so he can leave real soft. He's getting the idea now. He's not all braced up and tense like he was at the start. He's finding out it's okay. He throws the rope again and this time the transition to the lope is a smooth one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see that? He's getting better already. Pretty soon, if you work at it, you'll be able to make all these transitions easy on a loose rein. (sotto voce, wry) Yeah, and pigs'll fly. (to Woman) He's going to be okay -- so long as you don't go yanking on him. She nods, but he can see she's upset, feeling foolish. He walks the horse over to her, turns off the microphone and speaks sympathetically:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, the truth is it's all about self- preservation. These animals. (with great affection) ... well, they just have such big hearts, you know? There's nothing they want more than to do what you want them to do. But when the messages get all confused, the only thing they know to do is try and save themselves... Now, why don't you go saddle up and see what happens. Feeling better, and not a little attracted to his heartfelt man's man, the Woman smiles and reaches for his hand to climb over the rail. Her horse lets her come right up to him and stroke his neck. Tom comments;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They won't ever hold a thing against you. They're the most forgiving creatures God ever made. Turning on his mike and turning back to the crowd, he says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, who's next? A Young Boy leads a mule into the ring. Tom smiles:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now God has another idea entirely with the mule.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom has finished his "show." People are shaking his hand, thanking him, as he walks away from the corral, towards a trailer. The Woman in the Ralph Lauren approaches:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me. He faces the Woman:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. I'm Dale. I just wanted to -- I can't get over the way he felt under me after you'd finish with him. Everything had just, I don't know, freed up or something. The Woman is flirting. Tom shrugs, uncomfortably;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that'll happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you learn all this stuff?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What stuff is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About horses? I'd love to learn more about it myself. Do you offer any private lessons for riders?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... Dale... you know, a lot of this stuff... it just... nuts and bolts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if the rider's nuts, the horse bolts. (smiles) That's the whole lesson right there. You have a good day now... Just... keep on freeing yourself up. He leaves her, entering the trailer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small, well-used trailer. Tom and Rona are finishing dinner like comfortable old friends. Rona rises, taking the plates into the kitchen and starts rinsing them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh I clear forget. You had a call from some woman in New York. She sounded pretty wound up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't any woman in New York. But from what I hear, most of them are wound up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The number's by the phone. He nods but doesn't move. He just looks at Rona and smiles. She's a good woman. But Tom hopes she doesn't want anymore than what they have together. Rona notices him looking and smiles:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you looking at, young man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long were you married?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ever miss it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does a horse miss a saddle?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes. She chuckles, shuts the water off and crosses back to him, sitting beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well as a matter of fact, I don't... most of the time. She starts unbuttoning his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, Rona, we weren't all that good together even when we were good together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey... I was always good. Tom smiles as Rona leans in. They kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .Y.C. - MORNING Annie is looking over a magazine cover with Lucy and her staffers. She is unhappy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know it's perfectly shot, it's perfectly cropped, it's perfectly laid out and I'm so bloody bored, I'd rather buy a Motor Racing magazine -- Start over. Some general whines and groans as her assistant hands her a note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh, would you all excuse me a moment? She waits for them to leave as she sits before the phone. One of her lines is lit:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An endless sky. An empty ribbon of two-lane highway in Utah. A small roadside station. Tom's pick-up truck, his horse trailer hitched to it, getting gas. Tom is on the pay phone. We hear Annie's voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Annie MacLean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Hello. This is Tom Booker. I got a message you called.
direction.name: direction

location: A ROADSIDE SERVICE STATION SOMEWHERE IN UTAH
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: in her office:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh! Yes. Thank you for calling back. Uh, all right, let me try to explain my situation as briefly as possible... You see, my daughter had an accident with her horse... They were both injured and she, my daughter, she hasn't been able to... fully... uh... It was an extremely traumatic experience... and uh... Tom, sensing her turmoil, listening compassionately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I went on the Internet and found this article about you... It says you're a Horse Whisperer, that you... you help people with horse problems. And you have quite a success rate when it comes to traumatized -- TOM Well, see, truth is, ma'am, I help horses with people's problems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you know, however you want to put it -- I got your information from the publisher of the article. I called Montana and your sister-in-law, I think, gave me this number. (trying to be charming) I'm been hot on your trail you could say because I was hoping you'd consider coming to New York and taking a look at my daughter's horse and possibly -- TOM Ma'am, I'm very sorry about your problems and I appreciate what your daughter must be going through, but I'm afraid you've misunderstood whatever it is you read. I don't do that sort of thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if you could just come for the day. New York's only a few hours by plane, I'd have you home by dinner...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, even if it was nearer, that's just not what I do. I give clinics. And I'm not even doing them for a while. I'm heading back to Montana right now. I got a ranch to take care of...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll pay you for your fare. I'll send you to Montana first class.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ma'am, first class to Montana is a waste of good money. Now, am I being too polite here or when I say NO in Utah, does that mean YES in New York City? Annie is taken aback. Tom feels badly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't mean to sound insensitive. I understand your situation. But there's nothing I can do. You just called the wrong person, that's all. I hear there are a bunch of therapists in New York. Maybe you should call one of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Booker, if I could just ex -- TOM I am very sorry, ma'am. Goodbye now. He hangs up before Annie can continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie reaches for Grace's bedroom door, then pauses. She realizes she should knock. She does and whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace? (knocks again) Grace, it's mom. Annie slowly opens the door. She finds Grace's bed empty. She looks over to the window to find Grace sitting in a chair, in the dark, looking out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace. What are you doing? Not looking up, Grace speaks in a hollow voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't find that charm Daddy gave me from India.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I brought it to you in the hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh, I'm Tom Booker. Your mother around? Grace hops to the side as Tom walks by her, into the room. Grace is closing the door as he turns to see, for the first time, that Grace is one leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She'll be right out. She's on the phone. Grace hops back to the bed in front of the TV. Tom nods and puts his hat down -- noticing the prosthetic leaning against the window, near her bed. He hears Annie on the phone and looks to the other room, the door ajar -- seeing only her legs, seated on the edge of her bed, as she talks. Her foot taps impatiently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First time in Montana? Grace, rudely nods, still looking at the TV. Beat. Tom doesn't like her manner, but can easily see through it. He sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gonna be long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably. She's on the phone twenty- three hours a day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does she do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's an editor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mmm. An editor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not like books or literature or anything. Just a magazine... Just in case she hasn't told you -- which I'm sure she hasn't -- I don't want to be a part of this, OK? Tom just sort of nods. A beat or two later, Annie enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry about that. Hi. Grace, this is Mr. Booker... Have you looked at Pilgrim? Tom sees Grace turn away, just as Annie enters. He takes a moment. He could say no right there, but something stops him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh, no. I was gonna take a look now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want us to come with you? I just have to run to the main house and give Mr. Peterson a check.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't matter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace?... Grace, you want to come with us, take a look at Pilgrim? Grace keeps looking at the TV. No reply. Tom is half way out the door when he says to Annie -- making sure Grace can hear -- TOM Probably best she stays behind, anyway. He disappears. Annie gives Grace a final look and exits, closing the door. Alone, Grace flings her body across the bed, reaching for her prosthetic -- putting it on feverishly. She is completely intrigued by Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom stands alone at the stable. Opening the bottom door, ducking under the stall, he goes inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay now... Okay now... Walking towards him, Tom raises his hand, showing Pilgrim a sign of respect, of trust... He quietly makes his way along Pilgrim's side, along his flank, prompting Pilgrim to move out from the shadows, into the light. Tom moves to look at him. And Pilgrim suddenly kicks out at him. Tom, not cowed, stands his ground. He bends, looking at Pilgrim's withered legs. He looks up at his scarred head. He looks into the pools of the horse's tortured eyes. Pilgrim stands still -- allowing Tom this brief intimacy. As Grace walks towards the stable, she realizes that the door is open and Tom must be inside. She is amazed. Annie, appearing behind her, is also impressed. Tom exits the stable and sees them, as he closes the doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... You're closest anyone's gotten. He walks straight towards them -- veering more to Grace. He stops in front of her and they look into each other's eyes -- in a way that reminds us of how Tom looked at Pilgrim. Except, Grace is made even more uncomfortable by the intimacy. She turns away and walks to the corral, to lean on a post -- as if she doesn't care. Tom turns to Annie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to be honest. I still feel you made a long trip for nothing. He looks at Annie. Annie has no more words -- just an ever- present pleading in her face. Tom watches as Grace makes a small, naked movement -- putting her hand on her cheek, like a hurt child. He can't help but see these three being connected by one wound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But before I even think about it, I need to know something here and now. It's a question for Grace here. Grace stiffens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I work with a horse, it's no good just me doing it. It doesn't work that way. The owner needs to be involved too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that'll be a little complicated -- TOM You can make it as complicated or as easy as you like. But she's the one who's gonna be riding him, am I right? So here's the deal. I'm not sure I can do anything, but I'm prepared to give it a go -- (to Grace)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: if you'll help. (Grace gives a bitter laugh) You have a problem with that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't it like, obvious?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to me. Either you want to or you don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'll talk to Grace and call you later--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, with all due respect, but this is her decision, not yours. And I don't want to waste anybody's time -- mostly mine. Grace reacts anew to Tom's remark. She likes her mother being dis-empowered. Annie keenly understands the importance of Tom putting it this way to Grace. Grace has all eyes on her -- just what she wants. All waiting for her response. She turns away, flicks her head and says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, there's nothing else to do around here. Annie smiles in relief. But Tom isn't satisfied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not good enough. I can't help you. He starts walking away. Annie doesn't know what to do. Grace mumbles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do I have to do? Tom keeps walking out... Grace says it louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said, what do I have to do?! Tom stops and looks at her. Annie holds her breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank, Tom, Joe and TOM TWIN BOYS, 6 years old, sit at a dining table eating dinner, as Diane serves. We parachute into the middle of the conversation:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... well, I just think she's got a lot of nerve showing up here. Draggin' that child and that poor animal all the way... (TO ONE OF THE TWINS) You eat with those fingers again and you know what'll happen! (the boy cowers) Frank, don't you think she's got a nerve?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh hell, I don't know... According to Tom, she's a pretty determined woman. Must've thought it was worth it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess they'll want feeding and all, out here all day long.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe they'll expect that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, they ain't going forty miles into Choteau everytime they want a hamburger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mixed salad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe women from New York eat mixed salads. Ain't that right, Tom? Tom hides a grin -- he knows Frank into teasing her now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe so. Saw it on a television show, once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's just what we need on a cattle ranch -- a vegetarian from New York. Everyone eats. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you figure on branding?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Weekend after next...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the weather holds. Frank nods. Silence again. Everyone eats. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's an editor do anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not sure, sweetheart, but they eat like rabbits. Tom and Frank chuckle. Diane smiles -- in on the joke with them. The children are curiously confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera moves to reveal Annie on the phone in front of her computer and fax...  plugging in extension cords as she talks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... the phone company's putting in extra lines. I'll call back with the numbers. Oh, and I want you to get in touch with this lady in town here -- they say she's sort of a physical therapist for the rodeo boys but keep the one at the hospital we already contacted on call... Grace sits alone in the living room. Watching TV, but anxious and disturbed about what she's committed herself to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Diane is in her bathrobe doing bills at the kitchen table, as she listens to a BOOK OF TAPE. Her hand on her forehead, her other hand writing. Tom enters to take his hat off the sideboard. He moves to the table and reaches over for a cookie from a plate of cookies. Without looking up, Diane slaps his hand. Tom then pours himself a cup of coffee... then swiftly sneaks his hand back and grabs a cookie. Diane smiles. Tom exits. It is only then that Diane looks up after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera follows Tom towards his bedroom --  passing the others. Perhaps we see Frank sprawled out asleep already in his underwear. We might see the Twins in their bunks. One of the Twins' lower torso is laying outside of the blanket. He casually flips the blanket over the kid's bare feet and continues to his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom enters and closes the door. Turns on a stereo which plays a cello piece by Yo-Yo Ma. Books fills his room. He sits at his desk, puts on eye glasses and looks through some paperwork. Suddenly he stops, looking over the paperwork, into space. A thought passes by. We don't know what.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First light of day. Pilgrim stands stock still in the middle of the corral. Tom, motionless, is crouched on his haunches in the corral -- watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : As Pilgrim moves, he can see that the horse is stove up. He softly tosses a handful of dirt at Pilgrim's withered legs... Pilgrim, sensitive to the slightest provocation, bucks, wheeling away from him. Then stops. Tom sits on his haunches again... and watches him. Frank appears, exiting from the barn (perhaps).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Tom leaves Pilgrim, hooking up with Frank -- the two brothers go off, discussing the ranch work that is ahead of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie and Grace arrive in the Suburban. They exit. As they head towards the ranch, they see in the distance: Pilgrim standing along the fence of a round pen. Tom stands in the pen, holding a rope, looking at Pilgrim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom stands in the pen with Pilgrim. He looks to see Annie and Grace approaching but makes no acknowledgement. He turns his focus back to Pilgrim. Annie and Grace appear. Grace takes a position (that is to become her regular spot) a distance away from the pen. Annie moves in closer, beside SMOKEY (a ranch hand) with one leg up on the pen fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Howdy... (sees Grace) Howdy. He and Annie watch as Tom stands before Pilgrim -- turning sideways... then standing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trying to get his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's it going? Smokey doesn't respond -- how it's going is exactly how it looks. Tom takes a few steps, stops and stands still again. We sense the process is long and requires great patience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two hours later. Grace is in the same spot. Smokey is gone, doing his work. Annie has taken a different position, looking over SEVERAL PAGES OF FAXES on her lap. Tom is still standing in the pen trying to get Pilgrim's eyes. Joe has joined the proceedings, sitting on the pen rail. Tom deftly throws a hoolihan, gently lassoing Pilgrim around the neck. And Pilgrim, at the touch of the rope, crazed, resists, pulling back, striking at the rope... The rope cutting into Tom's hands. Tom gives him some slack, giving his head, letting him relax... then gently heads him by the rope, walking him around the pen, getting his feet to moving. Grace's eyes never leave Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom, off in the distance -- against a sky that seems to be touching the land -- is riding along a creek. Closer up, we see he's rustling the bushes with a stick. Some stray cows run out of the bushes. Tom races after them. His horse shepherds the cow across the creek and up a hillside. At the top of the hill, with the ranch spread out endlessly before him, Tom sees Frank on his horse, chasing strays. Tom whistles. Frank waves back. In the near distance, a pickup truck is parked on the range. Joe and the TWINS are throwing food pellets out of the back of the truck. Cattle come from across the range for the food. What begins as a handful of cows becomes dozens, then hundreds -- the truck virtually disappearing among them. Tom stops for a moment to look out at his ranch. Far off in the distance, he sees Annie's Suburban coming along the road to the ranch. He watches as Annie's distant figure gets out of the car with Grace. Annie instinctively turns and looks across the land. Even though there is such a distance, there's a sense Tom and Annie are looking at each other. Tom senses Joe driving Frank's truck, slowly moving off the range -- the Twins in the back, the cattle following. Tom sits on his horse atop the hill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pilgrim, his scarred head above water, legs moving in odd sycopation, swimming. We discover he is in a pond, tethered to a pole... Except for the sound of his legs in the water, everything is quiet and focused on Pilgrim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: holds the pole, walking on the outside of the pond, leading Pilgrim back and forth as he swims. Tom, crouched by the pond, silently concentrating on Pilgrim... Grace watches, off by herself... Annie stands beside Joe. She can't help but be intrigued by the sight. She asks Joe;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I though horses were afraid of water? Joe doesn't answer her. Grace likes that. Annie, frustrated, feels she has the right to simple shout out to Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that to get his strength back? Tom pays her no mind -- concentrating on Pilgrim. Suddenly, Annie's CELL PHONE rings, jarring the proceedings. Tom turns to Annie. She hides her embarrassment by answering it, walking away. Tom gives her a look. Grace is loving this. Tom turns back to Pilgrim. After a few moments -- Tom, taking the rope tether, unhooks it from the pole. He starts to lead Pilgrim out of the water. Pilgrim, fearful, fights him. He rears, splashing Tom, not wanting to come out of the water. Grace is worried. She looks to Joe and sees he is concerned too, though he stands quietly. Annie hears the commotion from where she stands and finishes her call to return to the pond. Tom enters the pond, waist deep in water, trying to grab Pilgrim's rope. Pilgrim rises up, rearing at him. Joe and Smokey, sensing danger, come closer to the pond. Annie appears beside Grace and watches as Tom reaches for the rope again. Pilgrim rears again. Tom stumbles backwards from his hooves. Annie gasps. Grace turns to walk away from the pond. She can't watch -- it brings back too much. But as she does, she is stopped by the sight of -- Tom, righting himself, unphased, calmly walks back to Pilgrim. The horse, baffled by this man's lack of fear, lets him take the rope and walk him out of the pond. Grace can't help but be impressed. Joe nods. Annie is shaken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Booker, I'm not at all comfortable with you taking those kinds of chances... As Tom leads Pilgrim out, the horse suddenly whirls, bolting, knocking Tom down...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God! Pilgrim runs off, pulling the wet rope behind him. Joe runs over and grabs for the rope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... LET HIM GO! Joe obeys. Pilgrim runs past the corral and down into a hill out onto a pasture, He keeps on running into the distance -- running across the pasture, not knowing where he is going... Tom, arms folded across his chest, watches him run. A concerned Annie approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's running away! How are you going to get him back? Tom doesn't respond. He walks off down the hill out onto the pasture, stops, arms folded and watches Pilgrim. Annie turns when she hears Smokey, who appears behind her:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He don't really want to run. Don't know where he's going. All this open space scares the daylight out of him. Confused, Pilgrim stops running and walks, in no particular direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My guess is he's spent his life in a six-by-eight stall... He's forgot what it's like to be a horse... Smokey ambles off and she turns back to see Tom crouching on his haunches, sitting in the grass, just waiting. Pilgrim walks back towards the ranch, stops a distance from Tom, looks at him... Annie, needing to know exactly what's going on, crosses down the hill to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what now? Should we leave? Tom continues watching Pilgrim. Annie looks at him, sitting there motionless and feels like an idiot. Clearly she doesn't understand all this and clearly no one thinks this is the time to explain to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we're going to go then... Without looking at her, Tom just nods. Annie, awkwardly, walks back up the hill to where Grace is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace is watching the scene by herself as Joe appears, staring at her leg... It makes her uncomfortable. She turns to him with a curt, impatient tone;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Their eyes meet. Joe is so guileless, Grace is taken off guard when he asks in such a compassionate voice;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does that hurt you? Grace tries to think of an answer -- and of how to say it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only when I kick somebody. Her gentle delivery makes him smile. She smiles, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you go to school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twice a month they give you a day off to work on the ranch. He tips his hat down as he looks out to Pilgrim with respect;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at him out in the pasture -- Yeah, he must've been a big, beautiful looking horse. How was he to ride? Grace is uncomfortable again. She looks away, just struggling. Joe senses she's done talking;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me. I got chores to look after. He tips his hat and walks off, passing Annie as she arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ready to go? Grace hesitates. Then mother and daughter take one more look -- POV -- Pilgrim standing in the pasture with Tom crouching in the grass waiting for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom is still sitting in the grass, just where we left him -- waiting patiently. Pilgrim is still out in the pasture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Afternoon shadows cross the ranch. Tom is in the exact same spot and position. Pilgrim is somewhat closer -- but still at a distance -- watching him. Frank rides back from work. As he passes Tom, the two nod as if nothing usually is going on. Frank rides up to the barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace is flicking the television -- repeating the only three channels over and over... Annie works at her computer, surrounded by work. She notices the time, gets a thought and dials the phone...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Mr. Booker... Oh, hello, Frank. This is Annie MacLean... I was wondering, has-... (listens) Uh-huh... And Pilgrim?... (listens) Still?... Uh-huh... (politely cheery) Okay then. Thank you. She hangs up, pauses, then speaks to the window out loud enough for Grace to hear -- ANNIE He's still sitting in that damn field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think they call it a pasture. Annie looks at her as if to say the last thing I need to know is a lesson on the local lingo...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go see what's going on, then get something to eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sky is changing colors, the temperature has dropped. Tom is still sitting in the grass, although someone has brought him a blanket for his shoulders. Pilgrim is in the pasture, but now -- he too is motionless, looking back at Tom. The sound of a car makes Tom turn to see Annie driving up. She gets out, stands by the car with a proprietary air, watching Tom and Pilgrim. Grace remains in the car. There's a sound. She turns to see Diane coming out of the house...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's coffee inside... I was just bringing this to Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you mind if I did? I'd like to talk to him. Diane, knowing full well Tom ain't in a talking mood, hands her a cup...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. (seeing Grace in car) Does your daughter want to come inside?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh, no, we're going to dinner... Is this the way to the pasture?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pasture? Oh, that stretch of field near the hill? Yeah. She's gone. Annie grimaces, then crosses the hillside to where Tom is squatting down. She appears to his side and, without speaking, tries to indicates she has his coffee by leaning it toward him. Tom sees her and accepts it with a grateful nod. Annie waits. Nothing happens. Feeling foolish, she begins to walk back. At some point, she turns to see Pilgrim moving across the pasture toward Tom. He stops in front of him, just a few feet away. Tom says something to him. Annie is intrigued -- and she knows enough to stay quiet now. She watches Pilgrim walk over to him. She watches as Tom gets up and pats Pilgrim's scarred head. In spite of herself, Annie is somewhat moved by this act. Only we see Grace, peering out from the car, seeing this act of communion as well. Only we see her reaction to it. As Tom turns and walks back to the ranch, Pilgrim follows him. As he passes Annie, all he says is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From now on, leave your phone somewhere else... As he moves past her, Annie responds;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I have business calls I have to -- Tom keeps heading for the barn as he suggests, without turning back;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then drop off Grace in the morning, go on back and do your business. Come pick her up around dinner. Standing there, Annie has the impulse to respond to this suggestion, but has no idea what to say and saying it wouldn't make much sense since Tom is already out of ear shot. Diane appears from the house and calls out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. MacLean -- why don't you and daughter stay for dinner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh uh, thank you. No, we don't want to impose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No imposition. Plenty of food. Gonna get pretty dark soon. Hard to find a place. Annie looks up to the alien sky and realizes she's right. She looks to Grace, who doesn't seem to oppose the idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone sits around the kitchen table. Joe, still wearing his hat, eyes Annie and Grace with acute curiosity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe, take off the hat -- I'm not going to say it again. Joe obeys. Diane puts the last of the serving plates on the table -- pork chops, potatoes, gravy, peas, bread... And a big bowl of mixed salad. The boy can't help eyeing how the "vegetarians" will act. Annie and Grace eye the food. Annie reaches out for a serving ladle, picking up Grace's plate to serve her as Grace reaches for a piece of bread, when:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dear Lord, we are humbly thankful for... Annie and Grace freeze as Frank continues his prayer -- they notice everyone's head bowed slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: these gifts. For the blessings on our home, our family and our guests. Bless those that aren't as fortunate. Bless all God's creatures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amen. Everyone begins eating. Annie and Grace breath a sigh of relief. Silence. Utensils hitting plates, the only sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bank out us a couple more men to run the cattle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should be fine, then. Beat. Annie and Grace listen...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Teacher asked me why we raise Black Angus-Herefords 'stead of Pure Herefords.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her they suit the weather better. Their udders are black, 'stead of pink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't get burned by the sun bouncing off the snow. And they're good mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our daddy raised Pure Herefords. Silence... Eating... Annie tries her hand at conversation:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, that's interesting. I always wondered when I went into a restaurant what was the difference between a regular steak or a Black Angus steak. I couldn't taste any difference although I could swear one was more tender. I didn't know there was that big a difference between cows... (silence) I've never been on a cow farm before. I must say, the bulls seem to have the best time of it. Just laying around the fields all day until they're asked to... (uncomfortable) do their... work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, get born a bull, got a ninety percent chance of getting castrated and served up as hamburger. On a balance I reckon I'd choose being a cow. (to Grace) Would you mind passing that salad young lady?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's Peterson's holding up for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's fine. Comfortable. I still can't get used to how dark it gets around here, though. When we leave the ranch, I always hold my breath until I can see the motel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, Tom, while you're working on that horse of theirs, Annie and Grace should move into the old Creek house. Diane and Tom react accordingly; Diane hiding her annoyance, Tom hiding his surprise and pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody's using it. Silly for her to be driving back and forth when she don't know her way around that well...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I don't know...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I know Peterson's. Old place is as good as falling down around your ears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're already all settled in, Frank. Anyway, I'm sure Annie wants her privacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's got doors, Diane. Private as can be. Tom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have a problem with that. It's up to Annie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's worth it, really? I mean, how much longer do you think you need to work with Pilgrim?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's up to Pilgrim. Everyone waits on Annie's answer as she considers this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace is on the phone with Robert. Annie is packing things up. Grace is telling him about the day;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Me, too. Why don't you come one weekend? Annie reacts to this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll have more room because we're moving onto the ranch. They have this empty house near this creek. It's actually pretty... OK... I love you. (to Annie) Dad wants to talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CENTRAL PARK WEST APARTMENT - NIGHT Robert is burning the midnight oil in the study with files all around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey... She sounds like she's doing all right. How is she? Grace exits into the bathroom. Annie talks softly;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. She seems to be getting more comfortable on the ranch, which is why I said yes to this move. But, whenever it's just the two of us, I don't know... Anyway... what's happening with the Delco lawsuit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taking forever. I just got an additional list of sixty-two employees to interview before Monday. I don't know how I'm going to do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's good that you're there. Robert didn't mean to validate his separation from them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, how are you doing in Marlboro country? Is the magazine complaining at all?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, but nothing I can't handle. Lucy tells me she thinks Gottchalks's plotting, but what else is new.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When are you coming home?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, I just asked that myself tonight. He doesn't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well then... maybe I will take some time... come visit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Beat. Annie knows Robert needed an invitation from her. But she can't do it. Robert tries again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I miss you, Annie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. We miss you too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Night. Awkwardly, they hang up. Grace exits the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you ask him to come visit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You already did.

One of the horses, PILGRIM, stays at a distance, off to himself. Grace watches from along the railing. She alternates her attention from the horses... to Tom.

(cracks the flag) ...When they've got a problem, like they have now with me and this flag, they look to each other. But old Pilgrim there has forgotten. I'm the rock and they're the hard place. He thinks he hasn't got a friend in the whole wild world... C.U. on GRACE, who clearly feels the same way... but wants desperately not to. She watches him ride off towards Pilgrim who has stopped like all the others at the far end of the ring. He stands by himself, tossing his head, snorting, not wanting to be around other horses. Tom cracks the flag, keeping them moving. Pilgrim does his own private dance. Tom rides by Grace and hands her the stick;

direction.raw_text: : The faces are beautiful. Laughing. Eating. Everyone is tanned and exhausted after a long day, but filled with life and eager to live it. The tables are covered with heavy food. The communion at this table is as much a part of the ritual as the branding itself... Annie and Grace look different to us. Tanned from the sun, their bodies sore -- they feel softened, yet more vital. As if the artifice had been worn off... the armor of urban life. As the table thrives with conversations, we focus on: Annie and Ellen Booker. Annie looks calmer than we've seen her -- and more naturally beautiful. She is seated beside Ellen Booker.
